SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.process
Class Process2

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.process.AbstractProcessSettings
      com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.process.Process2

@FullyTested
public class Process2
extends AbstractProcessSettings

Instances of this class must be created via ProcessBuilder2.start(). An instance of this class is guaranteed to track a started child process.

The following auxilliary threads may be created to manage child process input and output:

  • Write data to STDIN: If data for STDIN is specified via ProcessBuilder2.stdinData(byte[]) or ProcessBuilder2.stdinText(String), a thread is spawned to write these bytes to the child process' STDIN stream. A separate thread is used to prevent blocking in the main thread if the operating system or child process cannot read the entire data array in a single read.
  • Read data from STDOUT: A thread is always spawned to read data from the child process' STDOUT stream.
  • Read data from STDERR: If STDERR is not redirected to STDOUT via ProcessBuilder2.redirectErrorStream(boolean), then a thread is spawned to read data from the child process' STDERR stream.

In the standard JDK implementation of Process, the process' original argument list, environment, directory, and if STDERR is redirected to STDOUT are not available. This extended version provides the following method to access immutable versions of this data:

  • command()
  • environment()
  • directory()
  • redirectErrorStream()

Since this class and ProcessBuilder2 both extend AbstractProcessSettings, all settings for STDIN, STDOUT, and STDERR streams from ProcessBuilder2 are available from this class:

  • STDIN config via stdinData() and stdinText()
  • STDOUT config via AbstractProcessSettings.stdoutSettings()
  • STDERR config via AbstractProcessSettings.stderrSettings()

This class has many different ways to retrieve the child process exit value:

  • exitValue(): Throws an exception if child process has not terminated
  • tryExitValue(): Does not throw an exception if child process has not terminated
  • checkExitValue(int): Validates child process exit value
  • checkExitValue(Collection): Validates child process exit value
  • waitFor(): Waits indefinitely for child process to terminate
  • waitFor(long): Waits (up to a maximum number of milliseconds) for child process to terminate
  • waitForThenCheckExitValue(int): Waits indefinitely for child process to terminate, then validates the exit value
  • waitForThenCheckExitValue(Collection): Waits indefinitely for child process to terminate, then validates the exit value
  • waitForThenCheckExitValue(long, int): Waits (up to a maximum number of milliseconds) for child process to terminate, then validates the exit value
  • waitForThenCheckExitValue(long, Collection): Waits (up to a maximum number of milliseconds) for child process to terminate, then validates the exit value

Careful readers will note that many methods unexpectedly throw IOException. This is a wart of design. If data is to be written to the child process STDIN stream, a separate thread is spawned to prevent blocking in the main thread. If an exception is caught in this background STDIN writer thread, it is held and rethrown at the next opportunity. This prevents I/O-related exceptions from being lost in a background thread.

To better understand this issue by example, see destroy().

Author:
Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

stdinData

public byte[] stdinData()
Note: As there is no simple or lightweight way to create an immutable array in Java, a copy is made on each call. For huge arrays, this is very inefficient. Call this method with care!

isRunning

public boolean isRunning()
                  throws IOException
Tests if the current process has returned an exit value via tryExitValue(). A return value of null is interpretaed as the child process is still running and has yet to terminate.

All child processes tracked by instances of this class are guaranteed to have at least started. However, a process is not guaranteed to finish. A simple infinite loop may (un)intentionally prevent a process from terminating.

Returns:
if true, the child process is current running
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
See Also:
hasFinished()

hasFinished

public boolean hasFinished()
                    throws IOException
Tests if the current process has returned an exit value via tryExitValue(). A return value of non-null is interpretaed as the child process has terminated.

All child processes tracked by instances of this class are guaranteed to have at least started. However, a process is not guaranteed to finish. A simple infinite loop may (un)intentionally prevent a process from terminating.

Returns:
if true, the child process has terminated
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
See Also:
isRunning()

stdoutDataAsByteArr

public byte[] stdoutDataAsByteArr()
                           throws IOException
If ProcessOutputStreamSettings.isDataAccumulated() is true and bytes are read by the STDOUT thread, the accumulated byte array is copied and returned. This method may be safely called repeatedly during the runtime and after the termination of the child process.

Given that the data accumulation feature may be safely (repeatedly) enabled or disabled as the child process is running, this method is not guaranteed to return data unless the feature was enabled for the entire runtime of the child process and the child process wrote data to its STDOUT stream.

Returns:
copy of currently accumulated bytes from child process' STDOUT stream. May be empty array, but will never be null
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
See Also:
stdoutDataAsString(), stdoutDataAsString(Charset)

stdoutDataAsString

public String stdoutDataAsString()
                          throws IOException
This is a convenience methods to call stdoutDataAsString(Charset) where optCs is null.

Throws:
IOException

stdoutDataAsString

public String stdoutDataAsString(Charset optCs)
                          throws IOException
Similar to stdoutDataAsByteArr(), but bytes are converted to an instance of String using the specified Charset. This method may be safely called repeatedly during runtime and after termination of child process.

As Java currently uses UTF-16 encoding for String, it may be possible for badly behaving child processes to emit invalid Unicode text. Read more about invalid Unicode text in Java here.

Parameters:
optCs - Charset used to convert bytes to String. If null, result from Charset.defaultCharset() is used.
Returns:
copy of currently accumulated characters from child process' STDOUT stream. May be empty string, but will never be null
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
See Also:
stdoutDataAsByteArr(), stdoutDataAsString(Charset)

stderrDataAsByteArr

public byte[] stderrDataAsByteArr()
                           throws IOException
Retrieves raw bytes from child process' STDERR stream.

Returns:
raw bytes from child process' STDERR stream. If zero bytes received, the result is an empty byte array
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)

stderrDataAsString

public String stderrDataAsString()
                          throws IOException
This is a convenience method for stderrDataAsString(Charset) where optCs is null.

Throws:
IOException

stderrDataAsString

public String stderrDataAsString(Charset optCs)
                          throws IOException
Retrieves the text from child process' STDERR stream.

Parameters:
optCs -
  • optional Charset to convert bytes to String
  • if null, results from Charset.defaultCharset() is used
  • in the vast majority of use cases, the default value is acceptable
Returns:
text from child process' STDERR stream. If zero bytes received, the result is an empty String, e.g., "".
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)

tryExitValue

public Integer tryExitValue()
                     throws IOException
Tries to retrieve the exit value from the terminated child process.

Returns:
  • if the child process has not terminated, the result is null
  • else, the exit value from the terminated child process
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)

waitFor(long)

waitFor

public Integer waitFor(long timeoutMillis)
                throws IOException,
                       InterruptedException
Wait for the child process to exit and retrieve its exit value. Optionally, a number of milliseconds to wait may be specified.

Parameters:
timeoutMillis -
  • Maximum number of milliseconds to wait for child process to exit.
  • Value of zero implies "wait forever".
  • Must not be negative.
Returns:
  • if null, the child process has not yet terminated after waiting for timeoutMillis milliseconds. This scenario only occurs when timeoutMillis is non-zero
  • if not null, the child has terminated and the exit value is returned
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if timeoutMillis is negative
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
InterruptedException - if the current thread is waiting, but is interrupted with Thread.interrupt() by another thread
See Also:
waitForThenCheckExitValue(long, Collection)

Returns:
new thread to wait for child process to terminate

waitForThenCheckExitValue

public int waitForThenCheckExitValue(long timeoutMillis,
                                     Collection<Integer> validExitValueCollection)
                              throws TimeoutException,
                                     InvalidExitValueException,
                                     IOException,
                                     InterruptedException
Wait for the child process to exit, retrieve its exit value, and check the exit value is valid. Optionally, a number of milliseconds to wait may be specified.

Parameters:
timeoutMillis -
  • Maximum number of milliseconds to wait for child process to exit.
  • Value of zero implies "wait forever".
  • Must not be negative.
validExitValueCollection - collection of valid exit values, e.g., zero, one, etc.
Returns:
validated exit value
Throws:
TimeoutException - if timeoutMillis is non-zero, and, if after waiting for timeoutMillis milliseconds, the child process has not terminated
InvalidExitValueException - if exit value is not found in validExitValueCollection
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
InterruptedException - if the current thread is waiting, but is interrupted with Thread.interrupt() by another thread
See Also:
waitFor(), waitFor(long)

checkExitValue

public int checkExitValue(Collection<Integer> validExitValueCollection)
                   throws IOException,
                          InvalidExitValueException
Retrieves the exit value from the child process and checks it is one of validExitValueCollection.

Parameters:
validExitValueCollection - collection of valid exit values from child process, e.g., zero, one, etc.
Returns:
validated exit value
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
InvalidExitValueException - if exit value is not found in validExitValueCollection

createWriteOutputStreamThread

protected WriteOutputStreamThread createWriteOutputStreamThread(OutputStream outputStream,
                                                                byte[] byteArr)
Creates, but does not start (spawn), a new thread to read STDIN stream from a child process.

Subclasses of Process2 that want to subclass WriteOutputStreamThread will need to override this method.

Parameters:
outputStream - STDIN stream handle (Process.getOutputStream())
byteArr -
  • array of bytes to write to STDIN stream of child process
  • this is not a copy, so receiving class must not modify
Returns:
new thread

createReadInputStreamThreadAndStart

protected ReadInputStreamThread createReadInputStreamThreadAndStart(InputStream inputStream,
                                                                    ProcessOutputStreamSettings settings,
                                                                    String streamName)
This method:
  1. Creates a new thread by via createReadInputStreamThread(InputStream, ProcessOutputStreamSettings, String)
  2. Sets the name of the thread via setThreadName(Thread, String)
  3. Spawns the new thread via Thread.start()

createReadInputStreamThread

protected ReadInputStreamThread createReadInputStreamThread(InputStream inputStream,
                                                            ProcessOutputStreamSettings settings,
                                                            String streamName)
Creates, but does not start (spawn), a new thread to read either STDOUT or STDERR stream from a child process.

Subclasses of Process2 that want to subclass ReadInputStreamThread will need to override this method.

Parameters:
inputStream - either STDOUT stream handle (Process.getInputStream()) or STDERR stream handle (Process.getErrorStream())
settings - either STDOUT settings (Process.getErrorStream()) or STDERR settings (AbstractProcessSettings.stderrSettings())
streamName - either "STDOUT" or "STDERR"
Returns:
new thread

setThreadName

protected void setThreadName(Thread thread,
                             String prefix)
Adds descriptive text to identify a thread in a debugger.

Parameters:
thread - new thread that has not yet started
prefix - text to describe the thread, e.g., "STDOUT"
Throws:
NullPointerException - if thread or prefix is null
IllegalArgumentException - if prefix is empty or only whitespace

getOutputStream

public OutputStream getOutputStream()
Forwards to Process.getOutputStream(). Do not use this method unless you really know what you are doing. Writing to this stream directly, or -- worse -- closing it, will likely cause runtime exceptions in your application.

Returns:
stream handle for STDIN on child process

getInputStream

Forwards to Process.getInputStream(). Do not use this method unless you really know what you are doing. Reading from this stream directly, or -- worse -- closing it, will likely cause runtime exceptions in your application.

Returns:
stream handle for STDOUT on child process

Returns:
stream handle for STDERR on child process

              throws IOException

See Also:

destroy

public Process2 destroy()
                 throws IOException
Forwards to Process.destroy(). Use this method with care. It is not guaranteed to kill the child process immediately. On UNIX-like platforms, e.g., Linux, Solaris, HP-UX, the following C code is executed: kill(pid, SIGTERM), where SIGTERM represents signal 15. The process can catch this signal and gracefully shutdown. This is less than instant. Normally, SIGKILL (9) is used for an immediate, ungraceful shutdown, but is unavailable in the JDK.

Further, if a tight loop with Thread.yield() and hasFinished() is employed to wait for the child process to terminate, an IOException may be thrown by hasFinished(), especially if data is being written to the STDIN stream of the child process. However, if data for STDIN has finished writing, hasFinished() is unlikely to throw an exception.

Returns:
reference to this
Throws:
IOException - if an error occurred when writing data to STDIN (rethrown from STDIN thread)
